title: KEEN Targhee III Waterproof Hiking Shoes: Complete 2025 Review & Buying Guide
description: Complete 2025 review of KEEN Targhee III waterproof hiking shoes with expert analysis, user experiences, pros/cons, sizing issues, and seasonal performance insights from 3+ years of trail testing.

body:
KEEN Targhee III Waterproof Hiking Shoes: Complete 2025 Review & Buying Guide

Expert Analysis | Real-World Testing | Honest Review

After three years of testing KEEN Targhee III waterproof hiking shoes across diverse terrains—from the muddy trails of Olympic National Park to the rocky paths of Zion—I'm sharing my complete, unbiased review. These iconic hiking shoes have sparked debates about sizing changes and durability, and I'll address every concern with real-world insights from rangers, fellow hikers, and my own extensive trail experience. Visit our homepage for more outdoor gear reviews and national park guides.

Table of Contents

  • Overview & First Impressions
  • Performance Analysis
  • Sizing & Fit Issues
  • My Experience
  • User Reviews & Feedback
  • Frequently Asked Questions
  • Conclusion

Overview & First Impressions

The KEEN Targhee III waterproof hiking shoes represent the evolution of one of hiking's most recognizable silhouettes. Released in 2017 as an update to the beloved Targhee II, these shoes promised improved fit, better breathability, and enhanced agility. However, my three-year journey with multiple pairs has revealed both impressive strengths and concerning inconsistencies that every potential buyer should understand.

What immediately strikes you about the KEEN Targhee III waterproof hiking shoes is their robust construction. The nubuck leather upper feels substantial without being overly stiff, while the signature KEEN toe protection extends well beyond what you'll find on most competitors. The KEEN.DRY waterproof membrane promises breathability alongside weather protection, though real-world performance varies significantly with conditions.

KEEN Targhee III showcasing signature toe protection

Key Specifications

Weight: 17.1 oz (486g) per shoe
Drop: 12.5mm heel-to-toe
Upper: Nubuck leather & mesh
Waterproofing: KEEN.DRY membrane
Outsole: KEEN.ALL-TERRAIN rubber
Lug Depth: 4.5mm

During my testing across various national parks, from the temperate rainforests of the Pacific Northwest to the desert canyons of Utah, these shoes have shown remarkable versatility. The KEEN Targhee III series offers multiple configurations, but the waterproof low-cut version remains the most popular choice for day hikers and casual backpackers.

Check Current Price on Amazon - Men's Targhee III

Performance Analysis

Waterproof Performance

The KEEN.DRY membrane in the KEEN Targhee III waterproof hiking shoes delivers solid weather protection, though with important caveats. During my tests crossing streams in Mount Rainier National Park and hiking through morning dew in the Smokies, these shoes kept my feet completely dry for the first 18 months of use. The fully gusseted tongue creates an effective barrier against debris and moisture entry.

However, breathability becomes a significant issue during summer hiking. Unlike other KEEN Targhee III waterproof models, the low-cut version offers limited ventilation. Rangers at Yosemite specifically warned me about this during my July visit, noting that many hikers develop hot spots from excessive moisture retention in warm conditions.

Traction & Stability

The KEEN.ALL-TERRAIN outsole provides exceptional grip on most surfaces. With 4.5mm lug depth, these shoes handle loose gravel, muddy sections, and moderate rock scrambling with confidence. The triangular lug pattern in the center transitions to more aggressive perimeter lugs, creating versatility across terrain types.

Where they struggle is on wet rock surfaces. During a challenging descent in Glacier National Park's slick limestone sections, I experienced several near-slips that wouldn't have occurred with Vibram Megagrip soles. The rubber compound, while durable, lacks the sticky quality needed for technical terrain.

Comfort & Support

Comfort in the KEEN Targhee III waterproof hiking shoes depends heavily on proper fit and break-in patience. The CMEVA midsole provides moderate cushioning—enough for day hikes but lacking for long-distance backpacking. At 17.1 ounces per shoe, they're significantly heavier than modern alternatives, which becomes noticeable during extended wear.

The wide toe box accommodates most foot shapes comfortably, but the midfoot and heel run narrower than expected. This creates an unusual fit profile that works well for some hikers but causes pressure points for others. The KEEN Targhee III wide version addresses this issue more effectively.

Women's Targhee III on Amazon

Seasonal Performance

Winter: Exceptional performance in cold, wet conditions. The midsole remains flexible in temperatures down to 20°F, and the waterproofing shines during snow hikes.

Spring/Fall: Ideal conditions for these shoes. Moderate temperatures prevent overheating while maintaining waterproof benefits.

Summer: Problematic in hot, humid conditions. The waterproof membrane traps heat and moisture, leading to discomfort during long hikes.

Sizing & Fit Issues

Critical Sizing Alert

The most significant issue plaguing KEEN Targhee III waterproof hiking shoes is inconsistent sizing between production runs. Multiple users on Reddit and hiking forums report newer models running 6-8mm narrower than older versions, even in identical sizes. This isn't just perception—it's a documented manufacturing change that KEEN hasn't officially acknowledged.

During my testing, I compared shoes made in Thailand (2021) with identical models manufactured in India (2023). The difference is immediately noticeable, with the Indian-made version feeling significantly tighter in the midfoot despite identical size labels.

Fit Recommendations

Based on extensive testing and feedback from fellow hikers, here's my sizing guidance for the KEEN Targhee III waterproof hiking shoes:

Narrow to Average Feet

Order true to size but try before buying. Manufacturing location affects fit significantly.

Wide Feet

Choose the wide version and consider sizing up half a size for newer production runs.

High-Volume Feet

The low-cut version may not provide adequate volume. Consider mid-height alternatives.

Mid-Height Targhee III on Amazon

Break-in Period Reality

Unlike many hiking shoes that are comfortable immediately, the KEEN Targhee III waterproof hiking shoes require a substantial break-in period. The nubuck leather needs 40-60 miles of varied terrain to fully soften and conform to your foot shape. During this period, expect some initial stiffness, particularly around the ankle collar and heel cup.

I recommend starting with short day hikes and gradually increasing distance. The transformation is remarkable—shoes that feel rigid initially become notably more comfortable after proper break-in. However, if sizing is incorrect, no amount of break-in will resolve fundamental fit issues.

My Experience

My relationship with the KEEN Targhee III waterproof hiking shoes began in 2021 during preparation for a multi-park tour. After extensive research comparing them to alternatives like the men's specific models, I chose them for their reputation for durability and weather protection.

The first major test came during a week-long exploration of Olympic National Park's Hoh River Valley. Daily precipitation ranged from light drizzle to heavy downpours, and the trail conditions varied from well-maintained boardwalks to muddy, root-filled sections. The waterproofing performed flawlessly, keeping my feet completely dry despite multiple stream crossings and hours of walking through saturated undergrowth.

Testing durability on challenging terrain

Lessons Learned from Rangers

During my visit to Zion National Park, ranger Sarah Martinez shared valuable insights about footwear choices for the park's unique sandstone terrain. She noted that while the KEEN Targhee III waterproof hiking shoes provide excellent protection against the ubiquitous sand and grit, the rubber compound doesn't offer optimal grip on smooth sandstone surfaces common on trails like Angels Landing.

This observation proved accurate during my ascent of the chain section, where I noticed other hikers with stickier rubber soles maintaining better purchase on the polished rock. However, the toe protection proved invaluable when navigating the narrow, rocky sections where inadvertent impacts are common.

Seasonal Performance Insights

Winter testing in Yellowstone revealed the true strengths of these shoes. During sub-freezing conditions with intermittent snow, the midsole maintained flexibility while the waterproof membrane prevented slush penetration. The aggressive tread pattern provided reliable traction on packed snow and icy sections, though I still carried microspikes for extreme conditions.

Summer presented challenges. During a July hike through Arches National Park's Fiery Furnace, the combination of 95°F temperatures and high humidity created a sauna-like environment inside the shoes. Despite the KEEN.DRY membrane's claimed breathability, moisture accumulation became problematic after four hours of hiking. This experience taught me to reserve these shoes for cooler conditions or shorter summer excursions.

Professional review of KEEN Targhee III performance

Durability Assessment

After 450+ miles across varied terrain, my first pair of KEEN Targhee III waterproof hiking shoes shows impressive upper durability. The nubuck leather remains intact with only minor scuffing on the toe cap, while the stitching shows no signs of failure. The interior has maintained its structure without the heel collapse common in lesser boots.

Outsole wear is more pronounced, particularly on the heel strike area and lateral edges. This pattern is consistent with the reported 400-600 mile lifespan, though actual longevity depends heavily on terrain type and hiking style. The lugs show moderate wear but retain adequate traction for most conditions.

User Reviews & Feedback

Sarah M. - Amazon Verified Purchase

"I've been hiking in KEEN Targhee shoes for years, and the III version impressed me with its improved fit around the heel. The waterproofing is outstanding - I've crossed countless streams without a drop getting in. However, I did notice they run slightly narrower than my old Targhee IIs, so sizing up might be necessary for some people."

Pros: Excellent waterproofing, durable construction
Cons: Narrower fit than previous versions
Mike_Hiker - Reddit r/hiking

"Disappointed with the quality control. Ordered the same size I've worn for years, but these new ones are noticeably tighter. The construction feels solid, and they performed well in wet conditions, but the fit issue makes them uncomfortable for long hikes. Considering switching to another brand after being a loyal KEEN customer."

Pros: Solid construction, good in wet conditions
Cons: Inconsistent sizing, comfort issues
TrailBlazer_Janet - REI Co-op Review

"These shoes have been my go-to for two seasons of Pacific Northwest hiking. The toe protection saved me countless times on root-filled trails, and they've held up remarkably well to 400+ miles of abuse. Yes, they're heavier than some alternatives, but the durability makes up for it. Just be prepared for a substantial break-in period."

Pros: Excellent toe protection, very durable
Cons: Heavy weight, long break-in period

Balanced Pros & Cons Analysis

Strengths

  • Exceptional waterproof performance
  • Outstanding toe protection
  • Durable nubuck leather construction
  • Excellent cold weather performance
  • Wide toe box accommodates most feet
  • Strong brand reputation and support

Weaknesses

  • Inconsistent sizing between production runs
  • Poor breathability in warm conditions
  • Heavy weight compared to modern alternatives
  • Extended break-in period required
  • Limited traction on wet rock surfaces
  • Higher price point than many competitors
Compare Prices & Reviews on Amazon

Frequently Asked Questions

Are KEEN Targhee III waterproof hiking shoes true to size?

KEEN Targhee III sizing has been inconsistent, with many users reporting newer models run narrower than older versions. Based on my testing and community feedback, I recommend trying them on in-store or ordering from retailers with generous return policies. The wide version is essential for broader feet, and manufacturing location (Thailand vs India) may affect fit consistency. If you're between sizes, consider sizing up for newer production runs, especially if you plan to wear thick hiking socks.

How long do KEEN Targhee III hiking shoes last?

In my experience testing multiple pairs, KEEN Targhee III shoes typically last 400-600 miles of moderate trail use. The nubuck leather upper holds up exceptionally well, often showing minimal wear even after extensive use. However, the outsole shows wear more quickly on rocky terrain and aggressive hiking styles. Proper care, including regular cleaning and conditioning of the leather, plus rotation with other hiking shoes, can extend their lifespan significantly. I've seen well-maintained pairs exceed 700 miles.

Are KEEN Targhee III good for winter hiking?

Yes, KEEN Targhee III performs excellently in winter conditions and is actually where these shoes shine brightest. The KEEN.DRY membrane keeps feet dry in snow and slush, while the midsole remains flexible in temperatures down to 20°F. The aggressive tread pattern provides solid traction on packed snow and icy trails. During my winter testing in Yellowstone and Rocky Mountain National Park, they handled sub-freezing conditions admirably. However, for extreme icy conditions, I still recommend carrying microspikes for additional safety.

Do KEEN Targhee III run wide or narrow?

KEEN Targhee III has an unusual fit profile - the toe box runs wide and accommodating, but the midfoot and heel run narrower than expected. This creates a fit that works well for some foot shapes but causes pressure points for others. Recent production runs appear to be running even narrower overall, which has frustrated many long-time KEEN customers. If you have wide feet, definitely consider the wide version, and if you have high-volume feet, the mid-height models may provide better accommodation.

What's the difference between Targhee III and Targhee IV?

The main differences between Targhee III and IV include improved breathability in the IV through enhanced mesh panels, a updated midsole compound for better comfort, and refined outsole pattern. However, many users report that the IV runs even narrower than the III, and some durability concerns have emerged with the newer model. The III remains popular among hikers who prioritize the proven track record and slightly roomier fit. If you're deciding between them, consider that the III is often available at better prices now, while the IV addresses some breathability issues but may have tighter sizing.

Are KEEN Targhee III worth the money?

KEEN Targhee III offers good value for hikers who prioritize waterproof protection, toe safety, and durability over lightweight performance. At current pricing (often under $130), they compete well with premium alternatives. However, the sizing inconsistency issues and heavy weight may not justify the cost for everyone. They're particularly worthwhile for winter hiking, wet climate conditions, and rugged terrain where toe protection is crucial. If you can find them on sale and the sizing works for your feet, they represent solid value. For casual hiking or warm weather use, lighter alternatives might offer better cost-per-mile value.

Shop All KEEN Targhee III Models

Conclusion

After three years of extensive testing across diverse national park terrain, the KEEN Targhee III waterproof hiking shoes remain a solid choice for specific hiking scenarios, despite some significant caveats that potential buyers must understand.

These shoes excel in cold, wet conditions where waterproof protection and toe safety are paramount. The nubuck leather construction delivers exceptional durability, and the KEEN.DRY membrane provides reliable weather protection. For winter hiking, muddy trails, and rugged terrain with debris hazards, they offer compelling advantages over lighter alternatives.

However, the sizing inconsistencies between production runs represent a serious concern that KEEN must address. The combination of heavy weight, poor warm-weather breathability, and unpredictable fit makes them unsuitable for many hiking scenarios. The extended break-in period and higher price point further limit their appeal for casual hikers.

Buy If You:

  • Hike primarily in cold, wet conditions
  • Need maximum toe protection
  • Prioritize durability over weight
  • Can try them on before purchasing

Avoid If You:

  • Hike primarily in warm weather
  • Prioritize lightweight performance
  • Need immediate comfort from new shoes
  • Have had sizing issues with recent KEEN products

Final Recommendations

For hikers seeking reliable waterproof protection and proven durability, the KEEN Targhee III remains worthwhile—but only with careful attention to sizing and intended use. Consider the women's specific models for better female foot accommodation, or explore the full Targhee III waterproof lineup to find the configuration that best matches your needs. Most importantly, ensure you can return them if the sizing doesn't work, as this remains the most significant risk with these otherwise capable hiking shoes.

Ready to Purchase?

Find the best deals on KEEN Targhee III models and read thousands of verified customer reviews

Shop Amazon Now More Reviews
